s.text: This is particularly true if you're fighting for a job in the Clinton administration, where insecurity over the drug war runs high.

Belatedly, Weld is trying to regain the moral high ground.

Clinton spokesman Mike McCurry, who had refused July 21 to comment on "matters in the other party," was so moved by Weld's new plea for a "fair hearing" that he repeated that phrase six times at his July 31 press briefing.

Clinton spokesman Mike McCurry, who had refused July 21 to comment on "matters in the other party," was so moved by Weld's new plea for a "fair hearing" that he repeated that phrase six times at his July 31 press briefing.
At a July 28 press conference, Weld repeated his favorite question six times: "I'm going to be asking that one insistent question: Why should there not be a hearing?
Weld should have been able to play the victim, since Helms arguably started the fight by announcing in June that he would deny Weld a hearing.
